DOC.brief_summary: This study was designed to compare the efficacy and safety of an investigational nasal spray compared with placebo nasal spray and commonly used drug in the treatment of seasonal allergic rhinitis. Allergic rhinitis is an inflammatory disorder of the upper airway that occurs following allergen exposure. The focus of this study, seasonal allergic rhinitis (SAR), is one type of allergic rhinitis that is triggered by the pollen from trees, grasses, and weeds. Typical symptoms are sneezing, nasal congestion and pruritus, rhinorrhea, and pruritic, watery, red eyes.
DOC.brief_title: Study of GW685698X In Patients With Seasonal Allergic Rhinitis
DOC.criteria: Inclusion criteria: Informed consent Outpatient Diagnosis of seasonal allergic rhinitis with symptoms Able to comply with study procedures Significant concomitant medical condition Use of corticosteroids/allergy medications Laboratory abnormality Positive pregnancy test Allergy to any component of investigational product
